RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN -  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

RENOSOL SEATING
505 HOOVER STREET
FARWELL, MICHIGAN


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Facility

Renosol Seating endeavors in all its activities to promote a quality environment. Renosol Seating recognizes that our activities may impact our employees and the surrounding community. Because of this, Renosol Seating is dedicated to environmental protection, employee health and safety, regulatory compliance and pollution prevention through a strategy of continual improvement and teamwork.

Renosol Seating, Farwell, MI plant is ISO-14001 certified.  ISO 14001 is an internationally recognized environmental standard. The ISO-14001 management system provides the structure for continuing to examine and improve our environmental impact. Through these and other initiatives, Renosol Seating has implemented a system that holds each employee accountable for the safety and environmental performance of the company.


Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled

The Farwell, MI facility produces liquid polyurethane systems and polyurethane high resilient seating,   for the automotive industry.  Three foam lines are utilized at the facility using TDI (toluene diisocyanate). The other major chemical component to the product is polyol.  Only the TDI process is subject to the RMP requirement. TDI is a key component of the foaming line.  TDI, a mixture of toluene-2,4-diisocyanate and toluene-2,6-diisocyanate is received at the plant via railcar and/or tanker truck, and is stored in three storage tanks located inside the building. The TDI storage tank area has a concrete containment to collect and contain TDI in case of a spill.   Two storage tanks have a maximum capacity of 10,500 gallons each and the third tank has a maximum capacity of 7,600 gallons for a total storage capacity of 28,600 gallons. From the indoor storage tanks, TDI is transferred via hard plumbed lines to smaller re

taining tanks for daily use.  There is approximately 60 gallons of TDI in each day tank, 100 gallons in each section of process equipment and 18 gallons within the transfer piping system.  The total onsite maximum capacity is estimated at 29,098 gallons of TDI.

The TDI foaming line consists of a multi-station race track design line with each station containing seat molds. At the first station, the foam (mixture of TDI and polyol) is mechanically poured into the mold. The lid to the mold is then immediately closed and clamped shut. The foam is cured as it rotates through the various stations. The lid is then opened and the foam seat is removed. The mold is cleaned and a mold release agent is applied to the mold so that it can be used again.

The "covered process" (TDI) starts at the unloading area and ends at the robot head of the pouring station, where TDI and polyol mixture is mechanically poured into molds. The mixing of TDI and polyol occurs within the robotic head.


General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The facility complies with all applicable federal and state codes and regulations. The facility conducts weekly safety meetings and annual safety training and/or more frequently as needed. The process safety management at the facility for the TDI-related activities and equipment represents one of the facility's main active commitments to an accidental release prevention program. 

Renosol Seating complies with a variety of environmental and safety programs including waste management, storm water pollution prevention, spill prevention, community right-to-know programs (EPCRA), hazardous materials management, and emergency response. 

The TDI is stored indoors within a concrete containment system constructed in an integral fashion with the building. Strict procedures are followed when materials are unloaded including the requirement that a person observes the unloading of the delivery railcar or tanker

truck.

Fixed air monitoring equipment is installed within the building to provide an early warning of any TDI release. These monitors are inspected and tested on a regular basis to ensure their accuracy and functioning ability. The principle of detection is based on a chemical reaction caused by the presence of TDI on a chemically impregnated paper tape. A sample of plant air is drawn through the tape by a pump. When TDI is present in the sample, it causes a stain to form on the paper tape. The intensity of the stain is proportional to the concentration of TDI in the sample. A photo diode monitors the stain intensity as a chemical reaction occurs on the paper. If the intensity of the stain is above a pre-set level, the alarm relays are initiated and an indication is shown on the LCD display. The monitoring unit is equipped with audio and visual alarms whereas the display shows a flashing red light to indicate that the instrument is in alarm mode. 

Employees are immediately evacuated to a safe and designated gathering area outside the building. The alarm condition persists until a reading below the alarm set point is reached. No employee is allowed back into the area until a reading of below the set alarm is reached (5 ppb is the alarm level).


Five-Year Accident History

There have been no accidents involving TDI in the last five years.


Emergency Response Program

The Emergency Response Program is focused on the internal HAZWOPER trained team to handle accidental spills of TDI. Release events that are too large to be handled by the internal team are to be handled by an outside emergency response and clean up contractor. .  Renosol Seating has made a significant effort to communicate the elements of its response program with local emergency responders. Members of the local fire department and Local Emergency Planning Committee have visited the facility. Facility personnel involved with the TDI process receive regular training on pollution preventio

n and emergency response. This training includes participating in an emergency drill which is documented. Alert systems are also in place at the facility. As previously described the facility is equipped with TDI air monitoring devices to provide early warning of a TDI release.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Renosol Seating continues to review its programs and procedures and make improvements where necessary. At this time, no significant improvement needs have been identified.
